executive_summary: The performance of long-distance freight truckers largely mirrors the US economy. Spikes in consumer spending, manufacturing output and trade volumes drive demand for the industry's services. This correlation accounted for stagnated growth caused by COVID-19 in 2020 when a drop in manufacturing output and commodity prices led to a dip in spending on transportation needs. A sharp revival in economic activity in 2021 and 2022 amplified transportation activity.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: E-commerce Growth Has Boosted Demand for Long-Distance Freight Truckers
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: COVID-19 accelerated the shift toward online shopping, driving up demand for long-haul trucking services and putting pressure on the industry to scale up capacity. Even as pandemic-related restrictions lapsed, e-commerce sales have remained strong since many consumers have been exposed to the convenience of online shopping.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Driver Employment Has Encountered a Headwind
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Existing drivers have started to retire and younger workers have been less inclined to become employees, as they've been drawn to similar-paying jobs that involve less strenuous and mobile lifestyles. With stricter laws limiting legal driving hours, companies must offer competitive compensation packages to attract and retain professional drivers, ensuring stability and continuity in their operations.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Fuel Prices and Rising Interest Rates Have Constrained Revenue Expansion
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The American Trucking Association (ATA) estimates that even a one-cent hike in the price of diesel fuel costs could boost revenue by an additional $391.0 million in one year. Fuel surcharges are built into transportation contracts to offset volatile changes in fuel prices and create a degree of stability for profit. Supply chain disruptions related to the end of the pandemic and the war in Ukraine caused providers' surcharge revenue to skyrocket in 2021 and 2022, aiding revenue growth.

The boost in just-in-time inventory management, which demands real-time delivery of goods, has led to a significant increase in long-distance trucking activity to fulfill time-sensitive orders. Increased shipment orders, albeit smaller in size, have catalyzed an enhanced bonding between trucking companies and manufacturers, fostering mutual growth and more efficient supply chain operations.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Economic Expansion Will Spike Demand for Freight Transportation Services Nationwide
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As the US economy recovers from challenges related to high inflation, rising interest rates and recessionary fears, consumer spending will hike. This will prompt manufacturers to ramp up production to meet demand for their goods, necessitating freight transportation services to deliver inputs.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Safety Will Become a Priority for Providers
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Economic policies pursued by the federal government will favor freight transportation services. Investment in infrastructure benefits both demand for freight trucking and safety for drivers.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Technology Will Boost the Industry's Growth
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Fleet owners will seek to acquire hybrid, battery and plug-in electric vehicles to advertise a more environmentally friendly fleet and remove the uncertainty of fuel prices. Introducing autonomous or semi-autonomous trucks could drastically ease the current labor shortage, reducing the need for human drivers and spurring more efficiency and productivity.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Long-Distance Freight Trucking Will Endure Intensifying Competition
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Major companies such as Coca-Cola and Anheuser-Busch are implementing their own in-house transportation services, which will likely substantially lower revenue for external long-distance freight trucking companies, posing notable financial challenges for the industry.

industry_definition: Companies in the industry handle various commodities, which are often palletized and transported in containers or van trailers. Players typically provide trucking between metropolitan areas and regions that may cross North American country borders. The industry includes companies operating as a truckload and less-than-truckload carriers.

negative_impact_factors: low - steady Barriers To Entry Level

key_trends: Internal competition is fierce because of relatively low barriers to entry, which has resulted in downward pressure on freight rates. It's relatively easy for someone with little capital, experience or expertise to become a long-distance freight trucker.
The industry's main external competition comes from the Rail Transportation industry (IBISWorld report 48211). Rail transportation is more efficient than trucking in terms of fuel consumption.

E-commerce growth has significantly boosted demand for long-distance freight truckers. Thanks to the surge in online shopping, trucking companies are expanding their operations to meet the growing needs of retail giants such as Amazon and Walmart.

Aging drivers and difficulty attracting younger workers have created a hiring challenge in the trucking industry. Despite this, competitive wages and enhanced training programs are helping to fill the gap and ensure consistent service delivery.

As the US economy rebounds, heightened consumer spending will push manufacturers to increase production, requiring more freight services to transport goods. Companies should gear up for intensified demand and potential strain on logistics networks.

The adoption of electric and autonomous vehicles promises to improve efficiency and reduce labor shortages, while AI will optimize route planning. Leading companies are already investing in these technologies, highlighting a trend towards innovation and sustainability in logistics.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Manufacturers significantly rely on transportation services for the procurement and distribution of goods. This includes the conveyance of raw materials, intermediate components and finished goods between factories, dealers, wholesalers, retailers and transshipment points.

Retail and wholesale trade services cater to consumer demand for goods, often resulting in commodities being transported over large distances from manufacturers to wholesalers and retailers, more so than locally sourced products.

This segment includes demand from government entities to transport essential government consumables, including machinery and stationery, Utilities, Construction and Mining sectors, in addition to other sectors of the economy.

products_and_services.product_description: Truckload carriers are dedicated entirely to one customer and make door-to-door deliveries of goods, making this segment less labor-intensive than less-than-truckload (LTL) carriers.

LTL carriers take partial loads from multiple customers on a single truck and then route the goods through terminals where freight is transferred to other trucks with similar destinations, making this segment more labor-intensive.

Other transportation services include value-added services such as freight transportation arrangement and customs brokerage, packing, logistics consultation services and other related activities. Additional services include warehousing, distribution, repacking, storage and freight forwarding.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: The industrial production index, which gauges output from heavy industrial sectors such as manufacturing, is critical for long-distance freight truckers. Growth in the index signifies increased manufacturing activity, the largest downstream market for freight services.

business_locations.location_description: The Great Lakes region leads the nation among long-distance freight truckers. Chicago, in particular, is a transportation hub facilitating large shipments from out west that need to head to the East Coast.

The Southeast region houses a significant percentage of the US population and is characterized by its numerous establishments, such as businesses, educational institutions and entertainment venues. As a result, downstream demand for long-distance freight truckers is high in the region since these groups use many transported goods.

California plays a pivotal role in America's supply chains, acting as a land bridge for goods from Asia. They arrive by sea and then are distributed across the US via trucking routes. Shipping across the continental United States by truck cuts about a week of time off shipping compared to going through the Panama Canal.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The FMCSA is the leading federal government agency responsible for regulating and providing safety oversight of commercial motor vehicles (CMVs).
The EPA is responsible for the protection of human health and the environment. In 2007, the EPA introduced new regulations designed to cut nearly 95.0% of diesel fuel pollution.

regulations_points.regulation_title: Hazardous Materials Transportation Authorization Act of 1994
regulations_points.regulation_description: This law imposes strict rules on the movement of hazardous materials. The 1994 Act requires that all hazardous materials have shipping papers, be clearly labeled and have minimum insurance coverage.
To operate a commercial vehicle, drivers must obtain a commercial driver's license (CDL). Trucks must undergo regular inspections and maintenance to ensure they are road-worthy.

barriers_points.barrier_title: Relatively easy to become a long-distance freight trucker
barriers_points.barrier_description: It's relatively easy for someone with little capital, experience or expertise to become a long-distance freight trucker.

basis_points.basis_description: Internal competition is fierce because of relatively low barriers to entry, which has resulted in downward pressure on freight rates.
The industry's main external competition comes from the Rail Transportation industry, which is more efficient than trucking in terms of fuel consumption.

concentration_points.concentration_description: A truck driver needs a Class-A commercial driver's license (CDL) and can get a loan to purchase a truck to start a freight trucking business. This hinders start-up costs and reduces market share concentration.

Owner-operators primarily dominate long-distance freight trucking. The large majority of all enterprises don't employ workers and manage operations independently, underscoring their significant role in this industry.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Low barriers to entry result in downward pressure on rates
concentration_points.concentration_description: New entrants can take advantage of low barriers to entry since there's a lack of regulations, resulting in downward pressure on freight rates.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: These include equipment maintenance costs, the purchase of replacement tires and truck driver amenities.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: As diesel fuel prices hike, truckers introduce fuel surcharges
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: As diesel fuel prices hike, truckers introduce fuel surcharges because of the absence of substitutes for diesel, a unique source of fuel.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Outsourced transportation services to third-party rail and truck services
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Outsourced transportation services to third-party rail and truck services fill gaps in geographic coverage, and the available operating capacity of providers is the highest cost.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Soaring inflation has caused purchases' revenue share to rise
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Soaring inflation has caused purchases' revenue share to rise, although the use of surcharges have enabled providers to lessen costs for some expenditures such as fuel.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The industry's high capital intensity, requiring substantial ongoing investment in vehicle fleets, technology and infrastructure, can make it difficult for new companies to compete with well-capitalized incumbents.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Economic Instability Drives Long-Distance Freight Truckers' Volatility
volatility_points.volatility_description: Market fluctuations, brought on by events such as COVID-19, inflation and recessionary fears, have caused profound revenue shifts for trucking companies. This increased volatility necessitates major operational and strategic adjustments.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Fluctuations in Commodity Prices Impact the Trucking Industry
volatility_points.volatility_description: Variations in commodity prices, especially fuel, significantly affect revenue. These prices are typically passed onto downstream customers, impacting the cost of goods or services.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Driver Shortages are the Most Significant Threat to Trucking
volatility_points.volatility_description: Since the trucking industry has experienced significant growth, a shortage of drivers is creating bottlenecks, limiting the amount of work companies can manage and stalling the industry's expansion.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: VIRTUAL REALITY AND ELECTRIC TRUCKS HAVE BEEN MAJOR DEVELOPMENTS FOR LONG-DISTANCE FREIGHT TRUCKING COMPANIES
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Companies such as Tesla have made significant strides with electric trucks. Virtual reality (VR) is becoming a critical tool for truck drivers, providing advanced, immersive training experiences.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Advanced Telematics, Better Fleet Management and Burgeoning Blockchain Technology Have Been Introduced
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Advanced telematics, such as real-time tracking, boosts operational efficiency by optimizing routes and schedules. Blockchain ensures tamper-proof records for logistics and freight data.

FAQs.question: How has discretionary spending affected your major consumers?
FAQs.answer: Long-distance truckers depend on manufacturing, retail and trade markets to generate demand for their services. These markets were affected by changes in discretionary spending during the period.

FAQs.question: Is your company adequately prepared to meet changing environmental standards?
FAQs.answer: Operators have been incorporating new trucks into their operations when required to improve their environmental footprint. As new regulations are introduced over the next five years, operators must stay on top of the changing regulatory environment.

FAQs.question: Do you work with trade associations or other interest groups to advance your company's interests?
FAQs.answer: Industry operators work with trade associations directly related to the industry and those that serve complementary industries. The availability of individual contractors is crucial to meet industry demands.

FAQs.question: How does your company's profit compare with your main competitors'?
FAQs.answer: Profit is lower for truckers than for most rail operators. Within the industry, the ability of operators to adapt to changing fuel prices is a key factor.

FAQs.question: How have volatile input prices affected profit over the past year?
FAQs.answer: Volatile fuel prices have benefited industry profit in years with strong demand. However, the mechanisms in the industry to handle these price changes have been strained by the coronavirus pandemic.

FAQs.question: How do you maintain customer satisfaction? Are changes in demand revealed by major buyers?
FAQs.answer: Market research and understanding of market segments and client needs ensures delivery of superior customer service. The coronavirus pandemic introduced substantial changes in client needs and required flexibility.

FAQs.question: How do you make sure your prices are appealing? How do you balance price rates to stimulate demand?
FAQs.answer: Effective cost management through pricing policy, such as fuel surcharges, can help bolster profitability. Lower fuel prices and uncertain demand due to the pandemic resulted in greater price competition last year.

FAQs.question: Does your company have a recognizable brand? How much does your company spend on advertising?
FAQs.answer: Profit margins are often slim so large sales volumes are crucial. Strong brand recognition among leading operators enabled them to navigate the pandemic by promising flexibility and reliable services.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor the fluctuations in the price of diesel? How much of your revenue is derived from additional fuel surcharges?
FAQs.answer: Industry operators often implement surcharges to mitigate fluctuations in fuel prices. These surcharges and pricing schemes must be dynamic to remain competitive.

FAQs.question: Do you expect major changes in demand as a result of changing disposable income levels? How can you adjust your supply to account for these changes?
FAQs.answer: Long-distance freight trucking is sensitive to fluctuations in manufacturing, retail and wholesale sectors. Demand shifts can come from changing consumer confidence, supply chain issues and macroeconomic problems.

FAQs.question: Do you track trends in the freight transportation services index? How will you capitalize on these trends?
FAQs.answer: The freight transportation services index measures annual output of the US transportation sector. Tracking other indicators like shipping times and input costs can also benefit operators.
